The effect of Cu and Ni supported over mesoporous alumina catalyst was investigated for hydrogenolysis of glycerol in the aqueous phase to produce 1, 2-Propanediol (1, 2-PD). Nanocrystalline Cu and Ni supported catalysts were prepared by the hydrothermal method, and were characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM, BET, ICP-AES, TPR, and XPS. The effect of reaction parameters like temperature, pressure, and time were studied in detail. In this work, it was found that the Cu-nanoparticles are the critical factor for the selective production of 1, 2-PD. Mesoporous alumina support played an important role for the Cu and Ni oxide particles. The acid and metal function both played an important role in getting higher selectivity of 1, 2-PD. The reaction condition of 200 °C, 50 bar, and catalyst to feed ratio of 0.1 displayed the best performance using NiCuAl-1 (5%Ni, 62%Cu, and 33%Al) catalyst with glycerol conversion of 67.1% and 1, 2-PD selectivity of 90.1%. The catalyst was recycled five times for checking its catalytic behavior on the conversion and selectivity, and it was found that the catalyst did not change its activity during the recycle test, confirming the true heterogeneous nature of the catalyst. Graphical abstract Schematic representation of Aqueous Phase Hydrogenolysis of Renewable Glycerol to 1,2-Propanediol over bimetallic Highly Stable and Efficient Ni-Cu/Al2O3 Catalyst Image, graphical abstract Keywords Glycerol NiCuAl catalyst Hydrogenolysis 1, 2-Propanediol Hydrogenation 1 Introduction Glycerol known as glycerine is a polyol and, it is found in lipids known as triglycerides. Glycerol is produced as unavoidable by-product of the biodiesel production from triglycerides. It is also produced as a by-product during the fermentation of sugars for ethanol synthesis. Presently, the price of glycerol is low, so the effective value-added transformation of glycerol into fuel and chemicals has attracted considerable attention over recent years [1]. Selective conversion of glycerol is a clean and economically competitive process and represents one of the most attractive routes, allowing formation of different valuable products, such as 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PD) and 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PD) or ethylene glycol. Several review papers have been published in recent year reporting the utilization of glycerol for chemicals and chemical building blocks. The glycerol conversion to 1,2-propanediol by catalytic hydrogenolysis has emerged as one of the important processes, as 1,2-propanediol is used as a bulk chemical intermediate for the production of unsaturated polyester, resins, industrial solvent, antifreezing additives for food, cosmetics, pharmaceutical preparations, and as a lubricant for food machinery. 1,2-Propanediol is produced industrially by the hydration of propylene Oxide method [2,3]. Hydrogenolysis of CO bond in glycerol is the eco-friendly and attractive pathway to produce 1,2-Propanediol, as it involves a renewable source compared to propylene oxide route. External H2 is used in the case of the hydrogenolysis reaction to enhance the hydrogenation reaction. It is known that the hydrogenolysis, which occurred over acidic as well as basic catalytic surfaces. In case of acidic surfaces dehydration of glycerol initially form hydroxyacetone which further hydrogenated to produce 1,2-PD [4,5]. On the other hand over basic surface glycerol is dehydrated first to 2-hydroxypropenal, which further hydrogenated to produce 1,2-PD [4,6]. Hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-propanediol has been reported previously using supported transition metal catalysts such as Ru, Rh, Pt, Re, Pd including some bimetallic catalysts consisting of Pt–Ru, Au–Ru, and Ru–Re [7]. The bimetallic catalysts have higher metal dispersion and high surface area than the monometallic catalysts, which may improve the catalytic activity. Several reports in the literature using Cu, Pt, Ni, and Ru, loaded over C, Cr2O3, γ-Al2O3, ZrO2, ZnO, SiO2, TiO2, ZSM-5 and hierarchically porous SAPO-11 zeolite for hydrogenolysis of glycerol to produce 1,2- PD in continuous as well in batch reaction [8,9,18–21,10–17]. Transition metals i.e. Cu, Ni, Al, Co have shown better results than noble metals like Pt, Ru etc. [22]. Among transition metals used in glycerol hydrogenolysis, Cu has higher 1,2-PD selectivity due to its selective scission nature for CO bond over CC bond [23–25]. The use of bimetallic metals containing Cu like Ni-Cu [26–28], Ag–Cu [29], and Pd–Cu [30] have also been reported. Generally, mild conditions are reported for Cu-based catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol [31]. 13% glycerol conversion with 1,2-PD selectivity of 83.6% was achieved using 42 bar pressure at 200 °C temperature over Cu-ZnO catalyst [31]. Although several bimetallic catalysts containing Cu like Cu-Cr, Cu-Zn, Cu-Al, Cu-Mg, Cu-Ag have been reported in the literature for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol to produce 1,2-propanediol with low yield [29,32–35]. In this work, we have studied the hydrogenolysis of glycerol over highly stable and efficient Cu-Ni-Al containing catalyst.Several reaction parameters like temperature, pressure, reaction time were studied in detail to find the optimum reaction condition. The catalyst showed glycerol conversion of 67.1% and 1, 2-PD selectivity of 90.1% was observed at 250 °C and 50 bar pressure when the reaction time is 24 h. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2.6H2O), Copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2.3H2O), Aluminium nitrate (Al(NO3)2.9H2O), Tungstic acid (H2WO4), Tetraethylorthosilicate (Si(OC2H5)4), Boric acid (H3BO3), Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), γ-Alumina(γ -Al2O3) and Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were procured from Sigma Aldrich. High purity N2 (99.999%) and H2 (99.999%) were supplied by M/s Sigma gases and Services, India. Distilled (DI) water prepared in the laboratory. 2.1.1 Catalysts preparation The hydrothermal and impregnation methods were adapted for NiCuAl-1, NiCuAl-2, and NiCuA-3 catalyst preparation. For the preparation of NiCuAl-1 (NiCuAl-1(5%Ni, 62%Cu, and 33%Al) and NiCuAl-2 (62%Ni, 5%Cu, and 33%) catalyst, hydrothermal method were adapted, however for NiCuAl-3, wet-impregnation method has been adapted. An appropriate amount of Al(NO3)2.9H2O and Cu(NO3)2.3H2O were stirred and mixed thoroughly in 100 ml deionized water, while Ni(NO3)2.6H2O was dissolved separately in 10 mL DI water. The nickel nitrate solution was then added drop-wise in Cu-Al nitrate solution. Na2CO3 and NaOH (1.6 M solution) was added to the metal nitrates solution to adjust the pH ∼10, and the mixture was stirred for 3 h. After 3 h, the solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined SS autoclave (500 ml) and kept inside an oven for 24 h at 180 °C. Subsequently, the solution was filtered and washed thoroughly with DI water. Finally, it was dried overnight in an oven at 100 °C and calcined in a muffle furnace in nitrogen (reduce the agglomeration of NiO2 in the presence of oxygen and enhance the metal dispersion) atmosphere at 500 °C for 6 h. The catalysts were denoted as NiCuAl-1 and NiCuAl-2. Ni (80%) Al (19%) B (1%) catalyst was prepared by hydrothermal method. The appropriate amounts of nickel nitrate and aluminum nitrate were mixed thoroughly in 100 mL DI water and stirred for 30 min. With this solution, an appropriate amount of boric acid was added drop-wise, at pH 10, adjusted by adding NaOH (1.6 M solution), and the solution was stirred for 3 h. The final suspension was heated in teflon-lined SS autoclave at 180 °C for 24 h. The final precipitate was filtered with DI water and dried in an oven at 100 °C overnight and calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 6 h. Ni (50%) SiO2 catalyst was also prepared by hydrothermal method. The appropriate amounts of nickel nitrate and tetraethylorthosilicate were mixed thoroughly in 100 mL DI water and stirred for an hour. Then the NaOH (1.6 M solution) is added drop-wise until the pH 10 of the solution with constant stirring for 2 h. The solution was transferred to an autoclave and kept in an oven at 180 °C for 24 h. The resulting mixture was filtered and washed with DI water. Finally, the collected precipitate was dried in an oven at 60 °C overnight and calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C under N2 flow for 6 h. Ni (5%) WO3 prepared by Co-precipitation method. The appropriate amount of CTAB was continuously mixed into 200 mL deionized water at 70 °C with stirring. Then appropriate amount of tungstic acid added drop-wise at pH 9 by adding the NaOH (1.6 M solution). The nickel nitrate hexahydrate solution was added dropwise into the resulting solution. Subsequently, few hydrazine drops were added to the stirring solution, and it was continued for 24 h followed by filtration with excess deionized water. The solid precipitate was finally dried at 100 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 6 h. NiCuAl-3 was prepared using wet impregnation method. An appropriate amount of γ-Alumina (γ-Al2O3); 2.40 g, copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2.3H2O); 18.13 g and nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2.6H2O); 1.45 g were dissolved in DI water separately. The nickel nitrate solution was added drop-wise in γ -alumina solution, and after 30 min then copper nitrate solution was added drop-wise and the resulting solution was continuously stirrer for 1 h. The mixture was dried in an oven at 100 °C overnight and calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C under N2 flow for 6 h with a heating rate of 1 °C [36]. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The surface area and textural properties were analyzed by N2 adsorption isotherms at −196 °C with micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument by applying BET equation. The surface area (SA) was calculated from the isotherms using pressure 0.0–0.35, Pore volume (PV) was estimated from p/p0 0.99. X-ray diffraction (XRD) data was recorded of powder catalyst using Bruker D8 advance X-ray diffractometer instrument fitted with a Cu Kα radiation source (k = 1.5406 Å) using a graphite crystal a monochromator. Diffraction angle (2θ), varied 5°–80° with step size 0.04 and step time is 4 s at 40 kV and 40 mA. Varian ICP-710ES instrument used for metal content (quantitatively) analysis by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) method. The solid sample was made in solution/liquid form using hydrofluoric and nitric acid, followed by dilution. The reducibility profile has been determined by temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments using Auto Chem II 2920 Micromeritics instrument using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) in temperature range of 50–850 °C with heating rate 10 °C min−1, using helium as a carrier. The surface morphology has been done by Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) technique using FEI Quanta 200 F instrument, with the help of lanthanum hexaboride (LaB6) filament for X-ray source. The Image was captured by Everhart-Thornley Detector ETD at high vacuum (−7.0 pascal at filament), using secondary electrons and an acceleration voltage of 10 or 30 kV. Metal elemental have been captured/detected by Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). HRTEM have been performed by JEOL JEM 2100 instrument, operated at 200 kV with 0.25 nm nominal resolution. Alcoholic suspension of the solid catalyst sample has been prepared for TEM X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) data obtained by Kratos Axis Ultra spectrometer instrument having monochromatized Al Kα (hυ =1486.71 eV) source for X-ray at room temperature by using a hemispherical electron-energy analyzer working at pass energy of 20 eV. Spectrometer calibration was done by using Au 4f7/2 as a reference for the Fermi level at binding energy (84.0 eV) at operating pressure of the analysis chamber less than 5 × 10−10 Torr [37,38]. Conductive carbon over copper sample holder used for sample mounting and transferred directly into the analysis chamber. Charge effect corrected/ referenced by binding energies (BE) C 1 s peak (atmospheric contamination) at 284.8 ± 60.1 eV [38,39]. 2.3 Catalytic activity The hydrogenolysis of glycerol have been done in a batch reactor (Parr reactor with Model No. 4564) having 25 mL capacity. Glycerol was purchased from Qualigens with >99% purity. The reactor was provided with a mechanical stirring and a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller to control the heater temperature surrounding the reactor. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced at 450 °C for 2 h in a continuous flow of N2 and H2 (1:1 ratio) with a flow of 20 mL/min. After reduction, 100 mg catalyst was used for the reaction. The aqueous glycerol solution was prepared by taking 1 g of glycerol in 10 mL of DI water. After adding the feed and the catalyst, the desired H2 pressure was maintained inside the reactor, and the temperature was raised to the specified reaction condition. After attaining the reaction conditions, the stirring was started for a specified period of time. After the completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. The liquid sample was collected in a glass vial for high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis after centrifugation to separate it from the spent catalyst, while the gas was collected in a tedlar bag for refinery gas analyzer (RGA) analysis. The catalyst was also collected for thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), XRD, XPS and ICP AES analysis. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was carried out in Agilent 1260 Infinity II with a RID detector, using a HPX-87H (BIORAD –AMINEX) column (300 × 7.8 mm) with guard column (20 × 4.6 mm, 5 μm) using 5 M H2SO4, mobile phase, the volume of injection was 10 μL, and the flow rate was 0.5 mL•min−1, whereas column temp was kept at 60 °C, and refractive index detector (RID) temperature kept at 50 °C. The conditions were tested and selected based on peak number, symmetry, and resolution. Wavelengths were monitored from 210 to 400 nm, and chromatograms were acquired at 255, 270, and 280 nm. The glycerol conversion was estimated with below mentioned equation. Converion of glycerol (%)= (glycerolIN – glycerolOUT) / glycerolIN The selectivity of 1,2-PD (%) was calculated with below mentioned equation based on the area percent from the HPLC analysis. Yeild (%) = (Conversion) (%) ×(Selectivity) (%) / 100 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of fresh and spent catalysts are plotted in Fig. 1 a–c. The catalyst have crystalline nature with 2θ values of 32.5, 35.4, 38.7, 48.5, 53.6, 58.2, 61.6, 66.1, 68.1, 72.4, 75.2 are the characteristic peaks of copper oxide (CuO) in NiCuAl-1 catalyst (JCPDS Card No.81-0792), whereas 32.52, 35.55, 38.73, 48.74, 53.51, 58.30, 61.56, 66.25, 68.13, 72.40, 75.28 are characteristic peaks of copper oxide (CuO) of NiCuAl-3 catalyst (JCPDS Card no. 895897). It is noticed that high calcination temperature at 500 °C does not deteriorate the catalyst structure, and the metallic oxides remained intact with the catalyst. Two strong peaks at 2θ values of 32.52 and 32.5, 35.4 and 35.55 were observed for the 110 and 111 planes NiCuAl-1 and NiCuAl-3 catalyst. This plane is responsible for the reaction. The XRD pattern of the spent catalyst doesn't show any major deviation from fresh catalyst after the 5th cycle of the reaction, which reflects the catalyst activity doesn't change. The SEM with EDX image of the NiCuAl-1 catalyst is shown in Fig. 2 a and b. The Cu particles accumulated and formed a lump of larger particles at some places over the catalyst surface. It is mainly due to the weak interaction of Cu with the mesoporous alumina support [40]. The TEM images of NiCuAl-1 and NiCuAl-3 are shown in Fig. 3 a and b and Fig. 3c and d. As observed that the catalyst has a plate-like structure that lumps together hence forming the needle-type structure. From Fig. 3(b), it is evident that the Cu nanoparticles get accumulated at a certain place, as assured from SEM analysis too. The BET surface area of NiCuAl-1 and NiCuAl-3 catalyst was 26.3 m2/g and 55.5 m²/g (Table 1 ) and plot are mentioned in Fig. 4 a and b. The pore diameter was quite large, which might be due to the Cu and Ni interlayer interaction. The TPR patterns of Cu-Ni catalyst in NiCuAl-1 and NiCuAl-3 are shown in Fig. 5 a and b. The TPR profile is constituted of 3 peaks with a higher peak at 203 °C corresponds to the CuO reduction into Cu. The other two peaks at 185 and 220 °C corresponds to the CuO reduction into Cu1+, with small deviation to the pure Cu catalyst system, that is comes at 165 °C and Cu1+ reduction into metallic Cu [16,41,42]. Peak at 185 °C resembles the weak interaction, while the peak at 220 °C resembles the strong interaction of Cu with the support. The reason behind the lower glycerol transformation is the presence of Cu1+ in the catalyst, which is not reduced under the selected reaction conditions. The Ni2p and Cu2p XPS spectra for NiCuAl-1 fresh and spent catalyst are given in Fig. 6 a and b. The deconvolution of the Ni2p spectra showed the presence of three peaks at binding energy (BE) values at 855.31, 862.08, and 872 eV, and these are characteristics peaks for the Ni2+ and Ni3+ present in the spinel structure [43]. Moreover, the Ni2p3/2 binding energy values for the spent NiCuAl catalyst are 855.0 eV and 861.5 eV, corresponds to the Ni2+ and Ni3+, respectively . A peak at 857 eV is assigned to Ni2+ in octahedral (Oh) or tetrahedral (Td) sites of the spinel structure. O1s spectra shown in Fig. 7 b, where it indicates the presence of two peaks at 531 eV (main part, due to O2− -metal bond). 533 eV (minor component, due to OH bond) [38]. Cu2p spectra for NiCuAl-1 show Cu peaks between 932 and 952 eV, as shown in Fig. 7d. The binding energy found in the literature for the main Cu2p3/2 peak of the oxide CuO is close to 933 eV, with a shake-up satellite line generally lies at 945 eV. Therefore, the electron properties of Ni should be changed when Cu supplies electrons to the incompletely filled d-band of Ni to form alloy particles [16]. The presence of Cu+cation in octahedral sites is not clear yet, and most of the researcher accept the Cu 2p3/2 binding energy values in order as Cu+(Oh) < Cu+(Td) < Cu2+(Oh) < Cu2+(Td). However, in present case Cu cation co-ordination is distinguished in octahedrally and tetrahedrally. Therefore, the main peak at ca. 932 eV is due to the presence of Cu2+ for both Oh and Td sites. For both fresh and spent catalysts, the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks are followed by extended shake-up satellite appearance at 932 and 962 eV. These satellites comes due to the charge transfer, metal to the ligand (CTML) phenomena, i.e. Cu 3d to oxygen 2p orbitals. The spent catalyst also showed the absence of satellites in the spectra, confirmed that no considerable quantity of Cu 2+ species is left on the surface. The binding energy of Ni2+ and Cu2+ doesn't show any major deviation from spent catalyst after the 5th cycle of the reaction, which reflects the catalyst activity doesn't change. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Catalyst screening/selection Glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction have been tested over several catalysts like Ni(80%)Al(19%)B(1%), Ni(50%)SiO2, Ni (5%) WO3, NiCuAl-1, NiCuAl-2, and NiCuAl-3. The results are shown in Fig. 8 , which shows that NiCuAl-1 (Ni – 4.4 wt%, Cu – 60.3 wt% and Al – 30.7 wt%) shows high conversion of glycerol (67.1%) and 1,2-Propanediol selectivity (90.2%) was obtained at T = 200 °C, P = 50 bar, reaction time = 24 h, catalyst to feed ratio = 0.1. As Cu played a vital role in providing the base for hydrogen molecules to get adsorbed to its surface, hence helping in the hydrogenation reaction by forming 1,2-PD as a major product at an optimized condition. The glycerol transformation and product distribution of different catalysts are shown in Table 2 . Among all different catalysts NiSiO2 is the second best catalyst for this reaction with 45.4% of glycerol conversion and 67.1% of 1,2-PD selectivity. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature In the hydrogenolysis of glycerol, the reaction temperature plays an important role in the transformation of glycerol (0.0108 mol/g in deionized water) to 1, 2-PD. The variation of reaction temperature using NiCuAl-1 (0.1 g weight) catalyst was studied between 120 and 220 °C at P = 50 bar, reaction time = 24 h, and the overall results have been shown in Fig. 9 . It is noticed that as the reaction temperature was increased from 120 to 220 °C, the glycerol conversion was also increased from 15.5 to 53.3%. On the other hand, an increase in the temperature from 160 to 200 °C led to a gradual increase in the 1, 2-PD selectivity from 33.1 to 86%. Further increase in temperature decreased the 1, 2-PD selectivity to 52.5% at 220 °C. This is due to the fact that higher temperatures favor the CC scission, hence reducing the amount of 1,2-PD in the product [31,44,45]. 3.2.3 Effect of initial H2 pressure The glycerol hydrogenolysis was performed by varying the reaction H2 pressure using NiCuAl-1 catalyst. The reaction pressure was varied from 10 to 60 bar at T = 200 °C, reaction time = 24 h, and the overall results have been shown in Fig. 10 . It was observed that as the reaction pressure was increased from 10 to 50 bar, the glycerol conversion was increased from 22.9 to 67.1%. Further increase in pressure decreased the conversion to 59% at 60 bar. For the case of 1, 2-PD selectivity, as the reaction pressure was increased from 10 to 50 bar, the selectivity was also increased from 58 to 90.1%. Further increasing the pressure leads to a reduced selectivity of 79.9% at 60 bar. At higher pressure, the hydrogenation rates increased, which significantly reduced the 1, 2-PD selectivity. 3.2.4 Effect of reaction time The effect of variation in reaction time was studied from 12 to 48 h at 200 °C, reaction time =24, and the overall results have been shown in Fig. 11 . As the reaction time was increased from 12 to 36 h, the glycerol conversion was also increased from 36.2 to 80.2%, while at a higher reaction time of 48 h, it declined to 71.8%. In the case of 1, 2-PD, as the reaction time was increased from 12 to 24 h, the selectivity was increased from 53 to 90.1%. As the time was increased further from 24 to 48 h, the selectivity was decreased from 90.1 to 36.6%. This is due to the fact that high reaction time favors the hydrogenation and CC scission happens, which converts 1,2-PD into lower molecules such as 1-Propanol and 2-Propanol. 3.2.5 Recyclability of NiCuAl-1 catalyst The present NiCuAl-1 catalyst was tested for the recyclability study. As shown in Fig. 12 , the NiCuAl-1 catalyst was recycled five times at the optimized conditions to check its performance in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1, 2-PD. The catalyst after every reaction was separated from the liquid product with the help of centrifugation and washed three times with acetone to remove any absorbed molecules of glycerol in it. It was then dried in an oven at 100 °C, and it was used again for another reaction. Only a small amount (6%) of 1,2-PD selectivity was decreased after the 5th cycle of the reaction. This shows that the catalyst can be use many times without affecting the 1, 2-PD selectivity and the glycerol conversion. 4 Possible reaction pathways As reported in the literature, the dehydration reaction happens due to the presence of Brønsted acid sites [44,46]. In our case, the ethanol and ethylene glycol were formed with small amounts by CC cleavage during the reaction, but apart from this, a high quantity of 1, 2-PD selectivity around 90.1% was obtained. The presence of acetol also suggests this as an intermediate species formed during the reaction [47,48], which finally converted into 1, 2-PD (Scheme 1 in supporting document). 5 Conclusion Hydrogenolysis of glycerol has been performed in a batch reactor to obtain 1,2-propanediol (PD) as a significant product in the product mixture. The Cu nanoparticle of NiCuAl-1 catalyst played an important role in providing the base for the hydrogen molecules to be adsorbed and performed the hydrogenation reaction, which significantly produces good glycerol conversion of 67.1% and high 1,2-PD selectivity of 90.1%. Due to the absence of strong metal-support interactions Cu and Al2O3, the Cu particles were present in the agglomerated form on different parts of the catalyst surface, as confirmed by TEM analysis. It was observed that the reaction condition of T = 200 °C, P = 50 bar, reaction time = 24 h, catalyst to feed ratio = 1 was the optimum condition for the glycerol hydrogenolysis. The recyclability test for the NiCuAl-1 catalyst was carried out to check the true heterogeneity of the catalyst, and it was found that there was only a small decrease in 1, 2-PD selectivity after 120 h of reaction. At the same time, the glycerol conversion remained above 60%. coredata.dc:description: The effect of Cu and Ni supported over mesoporous alumina catalyst was investigated for hydrogenolysis of glycerol in the aqueous phase to produce 1, 2-Propanediol (1, 2-PD). Nanocrystalline Cu and Ni supported catalysts were prepared by the hydrothermal method, and were characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM, BET, ICP-AES, TPR, and XPS. The effect of reaction parameters like temperature, pressure, and time were studied in detail. In this work, it was found that the Cu-nanoparticles are the critical factor for the selective production of 1, 2-PD. Mesoporous alumina support played an important role for the Cu and Ni oxide particles. The acid and metal function both played an important role in getting higher selectivity of 1, 2-PD. The reaction condition of 200 °C, 50 bar, and catalyst to feed ratio of 0.1 displayed the best performance using NiCuAl-1 (5%Ni, 62%Cu, and 33%Al) catalyst with glycerol conversion of 67.1% and 1, 2-PD selectivity of 90.1%. The catalyst was recycled five times for checking its catalytic behavior on the conversion and selectivity, and it was found that the catalyst did not change its activity during the recycle test, confirming the true heterogeneous nature of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Aqueous phase hydrogenolysis of renewable glycerol to 1, 2-propanediol over bimetallic highly stable and efficient Ni-Cu/Al2O3 catalyst
